reviews.text: I put a ton of these in my house and had to take them all out that were tied to LED puck lights. The Smart Dimmers work great but the Standard digital dimmers interfere with each other when you have multiple circuits active. So if I turn on one room they are fine but when you turn on another room near it they will cause flickering. It is 100% the switch and not the lights.

reviews.text: I bought these dimmers for my house when I remodeled it. Within a few weeks the lights began to flicker. After countless hours of electricians, utility company personnel and my own hard work, we realized the dimmers were poor quality and the source of aggravation. My suggestion: Stay away from these dimmers. They cause your lights to flicker. And nobody wants that.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2024
reviews.title: Terrible. Lights flicker.

reviews.text: Needed to upgrade dimmers at my house now that everything lighting is going LED. These work well. The indicator light is a nice feature and is selectable as to whether it's used or always off (nice if you install these in a bedroom).
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2024
reviews.title: Nice upgrade for LED bulbs/lights

reviews.productTitle: ELEGRP Digital Dimmer Light Switch for 300W Dimmable LED/CFL Lights and 600W Incandescent/Halogen, Single Pole/3-Way LED Slide Dimmer Light Switch, Wall Plate Included, UL Listed, 10 Pack, Matte White
reviews.text: At roughly $9 bucks each these are a very good value. They dim the lights. They are no harder to install than any other switch. I've installed about a dozen in my new (used) home, both single and double pole. Cons - 1. There is a bit of delay in both on/off and the response to changes. You get used to that easily. 2. The sensitivity is not fully linear, nor particularly good. Controlling the dim at a specific level other than min and max takes some effort. The above mentioned delay does not help. 3. One of my switches does have a slight buzz to it - this switch serves 320 watts of incandescent bulb in an archaic light bar in my master bath. A trivial annoyance. 4. A couple of my switches have a bit of flickering at certain levels of brightness. One example is my pantry. Not a problem as this is a min/max application - min for late night snack searches. max otherwise. 5. I'm not particularly fond of the tiny white lights, but that's just my opinion. Notes - 1. I can't address whether the minor buzz or flickering is a result of cheap/defective switch or the nature of the load. 2. There is a very simple method of assigning the minimum dim level. Use it. Otherwise you will often find the lights appear 'off' when they are in fact 'on' but the minimum dim level does not illuminate them. Conclusion - Installing $30+ name brands would have cost me about $400. This job cost me about 1/4 that. I'll probably replace a couple of mine with higher quality switches where it matters. The master bath and dining room are are good examples. The rest serve their purpose quite well and are a bargain.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2024
reviews.title: Good value, with some sacrifices

reviews.productTitle: ELEGRP Digital Dimmer Light Switch for 300W Dimmable LED/CFL Lights and 600W Incandescent/Halogen, Single Pole/3-Way LED Slide Dimmer Light Switch, Wall Plate Included, UL Listed, 10 Pack, Matte White

reviews.productTitle: ELEGRP Digital Dimmer Light Switch for 300W Dimmable LED/CFL Lights and 600W Incandescent/Halogen, Single Pole/3-Way LED Slide Dimmer Light Switch, Wall Plate Included, UL Listed, 10 Pack, Matte White
reviews.text: I bought ten of these switches for renovate my house but my project delayed and now I found two installed so far are bad and too late for return. First I thought it could be my 125 amp breaker for my sub panel was bad because it make the buzzing noise (kind of disturbing, you can hear the noise clearly even the ceiling fan is on). So I replace my 125 amp breaker. But, it didn't fix the problem. I then turn off both first dimmer switches that I installed, then the buzzing noise stopped at the dimmer switches and the breaker. It's very much the dimmer is defected. Another issue is when you turn the dimmer low, the light started flickering and very disturbing. Now I am stuck with eight more dimmer switches which are useless. Should I waste my time to try out the rest of dimmer switches? More likely they all bad.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2024
reviews.title: Bought all ten but so far installed 2 and they both buzzing very loud.

reviews.productTitle: ELEGRP Digital Dimmer Light Switch for 300W Dimmable LED/CFL Lights and 600W Incandescent/Halogen, Single Pole/3-Way LED Slide Dimmer Light Switch, Wall Plate Included, UL Listed, 10 Pack, Matte White
reviews.text: These dimmers are great! I have installed them all over the house and have not had a single issue with them. I like that the locator light can be turned off. I have the locator lights turned on in hallways and living spaces, but keep them turned off for bedrooms. The electrical connections are my preferred design where a two straight conductors can be inserted and the internal clamp holds onto them. The line and load terminals take 2 conductors. The ground terminal only takes one conductor. It supports installation in a three-way circuit.

reviews.text: I bought a different brand for my last house and out of the 10 pack, 4 were bad. But, it was still cheaper than buying 6 better ones. I bought these for our new house assuming the same thing (that at least a few would fail), but none have been bad! They‚Äôre easy to install, especially not having to wire a neutral.
